lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can actively listen and identify key characters and classroom items mentioned in the story.
supportStrategies: (Listening) Before the story, show characters/items in the book. Say: “Listen for this: backpack.” Students nod when they hear it.
stretchStrategies: Retell the story with mixed-up objects. After the class watches or hears the story, change details (e.g. “He writes with a chair!”). Students listen carefully and correct you using “No! It’s a pencil!” Then let them try “silly story” retells in pairs.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can read the story, act it out and then answer questions using the target language.
supportStrategies: (Speaking) Assign character roles. Read the story aloud slowly while students act it out with expressions and repeated phrases.
stretchStrategies: Retell the story with mixed-up objects. After the class watches or hears the story, change details (e.g. “He writes with a chair!”). Students listen carefully and correct you using “No! It’s a pencil!” Then let them try “silly story” retells in pairs.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can create a simple, imaginative ending to the story orally or visually.
supportStrategies: (4Cs – Creativity) Pause at the final page of the story. Ask: “What could happen next?” Invite students to draw or mime their ideas.

items: Unstressed vowels do not really exist in Vietnamese, so these need extra practice. Make sure the final vowel of computer is a light schwa, not a heavy com-pu-TER. Same with the final vowel of banana. Or the second syllable of elephant. And so on.

In Vietnamese, final consonants are 'held in' – you don't actually hear them released. But in English, the final consonant of cat, top, rock, and so on are released with a puff of air. Make sure you are aware of this difference.
Do not exist in standard Vietnamese, written or spoken. The hardest part for YLs is learning to pronounce them naturally: there's a dog rather than there is a dog.
